Award.AwardTitle: A Model of Behavioral Evolution from Genotype to Phenotype
Award.AbstractNarration:
The evolution of behavior relies on changes at the level of the genome, yet few vertebrate behaviors can be traced directly to specific gene sequences. In this project, the research team will use a naturally-occurring animal model, the white-throated sparrow, to connect behavior with gene sequence in a concrete way. In this species, 50% of the birds have an unusual chromosome that makes them more aggressive. The chromosome is therefore an excellent tool for understanding how individual variation in gene expression contributes to variation in behavior. The team recently showed that animals with the unusual chromosome have higher expression of a type of steroid receptor in some areas of the brain. Here, the research group determines the genetic mechanisms, at the molecular level, that cause some birds to express more of these receptors than others. In so doing, the team demonstrates how responsiveness to steroid hormones is encoded in the genome. The work lends itself well to education and outreach because it illustrates basic biological concepts in a common backyard bird. Thus, it serves to integrate multiple units of a typical biology course in a way that is accessible to students. High school teachers are recruited to participate in the research and to develop lesson plans about genetics, hormones, brain anatomy, and social behavior. The PI also mentors high school students, undergraduates, and graduate students in the lab. More than 75% of the PI's mentees at Emory have been underrepresented minorities or women.

The evolution of behavior relies on changes at the level of the genome, yet few vertebrate behaviors can be traced directly to genetic sequences. In the white-throated sparrow (Zonotrichia albicollis), a chromosomal inversion segregates with an aggressive behavioral phenotype, offering a rare opportunity to connect genes and behavior in a concrete way. The inversion has captured the gene ESR1, which encodes estrogen receptor alpha (ERalpha). The research team recently showed that the local expression of ERalpha in the brain depends on the presence or absence of the inversion and that variation in ERalpha expression predicts the effect of genotype on territorial aggression. The research group uses in vitro reporter assays, bisulfite sequencing, and allele-specific quantitative PCR to identify the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms that contribute to variation in expression of ERalpha. The effects of selective ERalpha ligands on aggressive behavior in animals of each genotype is used to determine whether variation in ERalpha expression and function is causal for variation in territorial aggression. Because the team uses tissue from behaviorally characterized, free-living animals, the molecular and behavioral levels are integrated in the same animals to allow novel connections. The results provide an interdisciplinary, integrated model of how genetic change leads to phenotypic change. The work lends itself well to education and outreach because it illustrates basic biological concepts in a common backyard bird.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Behavioral evolution relies on genetic changes, yet few behaviors can be traced to specific genetic sequences in vertebrates. In this project, we provided experimental evidence showing that small changes in the sequence of a single gene have contributed to the evolution of divergent behavioral phenotypes in the white-throated sparrow, a common backyard songbird (See Figure). In this species, a series of chromosomal inversions has created a "supergene", in other words a group of tightly linked genes that are always inherited together. Half of the animals in any population have this supergene, which is associated with an aggressive phenotype. 

The supergene has captured the gene ESR1, which encodes estrogen receptor alpha, a hormone receptor known to be important for territorial aggression in many animals. As a result of being inside the supergene, ESR1 is accumulating changes such that now, the supergene allele is slightly different from the standard allele of the gene. Our goal in this series of studies was to show how these changes in the genetic sequence of this gene lead to the aggressive phenotype, in order to understand generally how a behavior can be encoded in the genome.

In our first aim, we showed how changes in a regulatory sequence of this gene, in other words a region that regulates how much of the gene is transcribed, lead to different levels of transcription for the supergene vs. the standard allele. These changes are both genetic and epigenetic, meaning that they affect not only the gene sequence but chemical tags on the DNA that can affect transcription. This part of the project revealed potential mechanisms by which evolution can alter the transcription level of a behaviorally-relevant gene.

In our second aim, we showed that the two alleles of ESR1, the supergene and the standard allele, are in fact transcribed at different levels in behaviorally relevant regions of the brain in free-living birds in their natural habitat. The activity of the supergene allele was much higher in one brain region in particular--a region similar to the amygdala in mammals. In birds with the supergene, the transcription level of the supergene allele of ESR1 was directly proportional to the level of territorial aggression. This part of the project confirmed that the mechanisms identified in Aim 1 are likely contributing to naturally-occurring differences in ESR1 transcription between birds with and without the supergene.

In our third aim, which was accomplished in birds housed in the lab, we manipulated ESR1 expression in the amygdala-like region so that the level of expression in birds with the supergene allele was "knocked down" to levels more typical of birds with only the standard allele. As expected, the birds with the knockdown behaved less aggressively; in other words, the birds with the supergene allele, which normally would be more aggressive, were less aggressive when ESR1 expression was experimentally reduced. This part of the project showed that the behavioral phenotype can be at least partly explained by expression of this one gene, since we were able to change the more aggressive phenotype into the less aggressive one just by reducing the expression of the gene.

Overall, the work has provided a rare illustration of how social behaviors can be encoded in the genome and how they evolve.
